questions.question: How many types of hypersensitivity reactions are classically described?
questions.explanation: Gell and Coombs classified hypersensitivity into 4 main types: I (immediate), II (cytotoxic), III (immune complex), and IV (delayed).

questions.question: Which immunoglobulin is central to Type I hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE binding to allergens and activating mast cells and basophils.

questions.question: Type II hypersensitivity is mainly caused by:
questions.explanation: Type II involves IgG or IgM antibodies binding to antigens on cell surfaces, leading to complement activation and cell destruction.

questions.question: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with serum sickness?
questions.explanation: Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complex deposition, as seen in serum sickness and systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.question: Which type of hypersensitivity is also called 'delayed type'?
questions.explanation: Type IV hypersensitivity is mediated by T cells and typically develops 48–72 hours after antigen exposure.

questions.question: Which cells release histamine in Type I hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Upon allergen exposure, IgE cross-links on mast cells and basophils, leading to histamine release.

questions.question: Asthma and allergic rhinitis are examples of which hypersensitivity type?
questions.explanation: Both asthma and allergic rhinitis are IgE-mediated Type I hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.question: Hemolytic disease of the newborn is an example of which hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Type II cytotoxic reaction occurs when maternal IgG crosses the placenta and destroys fetal red blood cells.

questions.question: Goodpasture syndrome is caused by:
questions.explanation: Goodpasture syndrome is a Type II hypersensitivity caused by antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.question: Which laboratory test is useful for diagnosing Type I hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Skin prick tests identify allergens that trigger IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.question: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an example of which hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: SLE involves immune complex deposition in tissues, characteristic of Type III hypersensitivity.

questions.question: Which condition is a classic example of Type IV hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Contact dermatitis, such as poison ivy reaction, is mediated by T cells and cytokines (delayed type).

questions.question: Which immune cells mediate Type IV hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: Type IV is driven by CD4+ Th1 and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, not antibodies.

questions.question: The tuberculin skin test (Mantoux test) is based on which hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation: The tuberculin test depends on T-cell memory response, developing 48–72 hours after exposure.

questions.question: Which type of hypersensitivity is most associated with chronic transplant rejection?
questions.explanation: Chronic transplant rejection involves T cell–mediated responses, typical of Type IV hypersensitivity.
